Twenty-five healthy adults agreed to participate in the study and add <math alttext="3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of chocolate to their daily diets. Of the <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> participants, <math alttext="13" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>13</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> were randomly assigned to the dark chocolate group and the rest were assigned to the white chocolate group. All participants had their blood pressure recorded, in millimeters of mercury (<math alttext="m m H g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mmHg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), before adding chocolate to their daily diets and again <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days after adding chocolate to their daily diets.

The reduction in blood pressure (before minus after) for each of the participants in the two groups is shown in the dotplots below.

(a) Determine and compare the medians of the reduction in blood pressure for the two groups.

The researchers found the mean reduction in blood pressure for those who consumed dark chocolate is <math alttext="x bar sub dark, equals 6.08 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>6.08</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="millimeters of mercury" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mmHg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the mean reduction in blood pressure for those who consumed white chocolate is <math alttext="x bar sub white, equals 0.42 " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>w</mi><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.42</mn></mrow></math> <math alttext="millimeter of mercury" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mmHg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) One researcher indicated that because the difference in sample means of <math alttext="5.66" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.66</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="millimeters of mercury " overflow="scroll"><mtext>mmHg</mtext></math> is greater than <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> there is convincing statistical evidence to conclude that the population mean blood pressure reduction for those who consume dark chocolate is greater than for those who consume white chocolate. Why might the researcher’s conclusion, based only on the difference in sample means of <math alttext="5.66" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.66</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="millimeters of mercury " overflow="scroll"><mtext>mmHg</mtext></math>, not necessarily be true?

A simulation was conducted to investigate whether there is a greater reduction of blood pressure for those who consume dark chocolate than for those who consume white chocolate. The simulation was conducted under the assumption that no difference exists. The results of <math alttext="120" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> trials of the simulation are shown in the following dotplot.

(c) Use the results of the simulation to determine whether the results from the <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> participants in the study provide convincing statistical evidence, at a <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> percent level of significance, that adding dark chocolate to a daily diet will result in a greater reduction in blood pressure, on average, than adding white chocolate to a daily diet. Justify your answer.
